review.title: How to Maximize User Satisfaction Degree in Multi-service IP Networks
review.abstract: Bandwidth allocation is a fundamental problem in communication networks. With current network moving towards the Future Internet model, the problem is further intensified as network traffic demanding far from exceeds network bandwidth capability. Maintaining a certain user satisfaction degree therefore becomes a challenge research topic. In this paper, we deal with the problem by proposing BASMIN, a novel bandwidth allocation scheme that aims to maximize network user's happiness. We also defined a new metric for evaluating network user satisfaction degree: network worth. A three-step evaluation process is then conducted to compare BASMIN efficiency with other three popular bandwidth allocation schemes. Throughout the tests, we experienced BASMIN's advantages over the others; we even found out that one of the most widely used bandwidth allocation schemes, in fact, is not effective at all.

sections.heading: B. Hard-Real Time application
sections.text: Hard Real-Time (HRT) applications are the most delay-sensitive applications. These applications require their data to arrive within a specified delay limit, require strict end-to-end performance guarantees, and show no adaptive characteristics. A network flow belonging to this type of application must not enter the network if the minimum bandwidth requirement cannot be met; and once accepted, the allocated bandwidth is determined during the lifetime of the network session. Higher bandwidth allocation should not lead to an increase in performance, while degradation of bandwidth causes QoS (utility) to fall to zero. Examples of this are audio / video phones, video conferencing, and telemedicine. The utility function used to model HRT traffic is: max () 1 kbb eU b (2), with bmax being the bandwidth required.
